title-group.article-title: Minimally Invasive Osteotomy for Symptomatic Bunionette Deformity Is Not Advisable for Severe Deformities
title-group.subtitle: A Critical Retrospective Analysis of the Results

contrib-group.aff: Orthopaedic Department, Hannover Medical School, Hannover, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Hazibullah Waizy, MD, Orthopaedic Department, Hannover Medical School, Anna-von-Borries Straße 1-7, 30625 Hannover, Germany; e-mail: hwaizy@yahoo.com.

abstract.p: Bunionette, or tailor’s bunion, is a painful protrusion on the plantar and/or lateral aspect of the fifth metatarsal head. Until recently, there have been very good results reported in literature when minimally invasive therapy is used to treat this deformity. In this study, the authors critically review the outcome of patients operated by the minimal invasive technique. A total of 31 feet were retrospectively reviewed with a mean follow-up of 52 months (range 14-106 months). The results were related to the preoperative severity of the bunionette deformity. The mean intermetatarsal angle IV/V was reduced from 12° to 7.5° postoperatively. The American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society score showed good and excellent values (80-100 points) at follow-up in 16 (12 type I, 4 type III) feet. Fourteen (2 type I, 5 type II, 7 type III) feet were rated as satisfactory (60-80 points) and one (type III) foot with fair (56 points). Nine patients (5 type II and 4 type III) indicated that they would not undergo the operative procedure again. Our results show inclusive evidence that minimal invasive osteotomies have a good clinical outcome in the treatment of high-grade deformities. The best future option is to consider the classification of the deformity before a minimally invasive operation is to take place.
Levels of Evidence: Prognostic, Level IV, Case series

body.p: Bunionette, or tailor’s bunion, is a painful osseous prominence on the lateral aspect of the head of the fifth metatarsal bone. Lateral pressure and contact friction against the fifth metatarsal head often occurs in adults who wear improperly fitting shoes. The enlarged varus-valgus mobility of the fifth metatarsal bone may be a factor for developing the lateral deviation. Bunionette pathology is also observed in congenital cases when the fifth metarsal head displays a widened or dumbbell shape. Symptoms in these patients usually include pain, erythema, hyperkeratosis, and swelling at the lateral border of the fifth metatarsale head.1,2

disp-quote.p: “The best future option is to consider the classification of the deformity before a minimally invasive operation is to take place.”

body.p: In healthy patients without a bunion, the diameter of the fifth metatarsal head is less than 13 mm, the intermetatarsal angel IV/V (IM IV/V) is usually less than 6.5° with a range of 3° to 11° and the metatarsophalangeal angle (MTP) is less than 14°.1-4 Fallat5 classified 3 types of bunionette deformities (Figure 1). Type I is described as an enlargement of the lateral aspect of the fifth metatarsal head. A lateral bowing at the neck of the fifth metatarsal bone with an enlarged MTP of more than 14° is characterized as type II. In patients with a type III deformity, the IM IV/V is greater than 6.5°. The goal of the operative treatment should be to address the specific pathology of each deformity type.

caption.p: Three types of bunionette deformities according to Fallat5

Type I is defined by enlargement of the lateral aspect of the fifth metatarsal head. The intermetatarsal angle (A) is not increased. Type II is described as a lateral bowing of the distal aspect of the fifth metatarsal bone without hypertrophy of the metatarsal head. The lateral bowing is measured by drawing a line bisecting the midpoint of the articular surface of the head and the neck. Another line is drawn adjacent and parallel to the medial surface of the proximal metatarsal bone. Angle (B) represents the fifth metatarsophalangeal angle (MTP). Type III is defined by an increased intermetatarsal angle (C).

body.p: Conservative treatment is the initial therapeutic approach in patients with symptomatic bunion with pressure reduction on the lateral aspect of the fifth metatarsal head. Shoe modifications with a wide toe-box or insoles may be helpful. Debridement of the hyperceratosis may also relieve pain. Anti-inflammatory drugs or steroid injections are helpful in acute situations. In most cases, however, the conservative therapy fails and a surgical procedure is necessary. Several operative treatments such as bunionectomy, resection of the fifth metatarsal head, and osteotomies of the neck, shaft, or the basis are described in literature.6-20 Recently, several authors report about good to excellent results about minimal invasive osteotomy techniques in bunionette surgery.8,14,19,21 The aim of this study was a critical retrospective evaluation of our results of the minimal invasive bunionette osteotomy with regard to the preoperative severity of the bunionette deformity.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The study was approved by an internal review board. The patients gave their informed consent to participate in the study. We retrospectively evaluated 20 consecutive patients (31 feet) who were operated with a minimally invasive bunionette osteotomy (Figures 2A and B). Eleven patients were operated on both feet simultaneously and 9 patients were operated only on one side. The deformities in these patients were not associated with rheumatoid arthritis. All patients were female with a symptomatic bunionette deformity and failed conservative therapy. The minimum time of conservative treatment was 12 months. The conservative therapy included shoe modifications or insoles. The average age at time of operation was 35 years (range 17-66 years). Eight feet also had a distal chevron osteotomy of the first metatarsal bone because of the presence of hallux valgus deformity.

caption.p: A, The osteotomy goes from lateral–proximal to medial–distal. B The head is displaced medially and the K-wire is forwarded into the metatarsal shaft.

sec.p: Preoperative weight-bearing posterior–anterior and lateral radiographs were taken to stage the bunionette deformity according to Fallat.5 In total, 15 feet were categorized as type I, 5 feet as type II, and 11 feet as type III. The preoperative and the postoperative X-rays were also analyzed with regard to the length of the metatarsal V bone. The length was defined as the distance between the tip of the metatarsal V bone and the midpoint of the tarsometatarsal V joint. Follow-up was possible in all patients with a mean follow-up time of 52 months (range 14-106 months). At follow-up, the clinical evaluation included the lesser toe American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) score. The results were graded as excellent (90-100 points), good (80-89 points), satisfactory (70-79 points), and poor (<70 points). The radiographic evaluation compared preoperative and postoperative IM IV/V and MTP angles.

sec.title: Operative Technique
sec.p: There was a standard procedure for all patients. The patient was placed in supine position with a tourniquet bandage at the ankle. A 1-cm longitudinal incision was placed laterally at the fifth metatarsal head–neck junction. Then a 1.4-mm K-wire was inserted at the lateral tip of the fifth phalanx and placed (from distal to proximal) along the lateral aspect of the phalanx until the MTP V joint. The capsule and periosteum was incised subcapital and an oblique osteotomy of the fifth metatarsal bone was done from lateral–distal to medial–proximal with a saw (Figure 2). The metatarsal head was then displaced medially and the K-wire was forwarded into the metatarsal shaft until a stable K-wire position was achieved. The capsule was repaired by one suture. Full weight-bearing was allowed with a stiff-soled postoperative shoe for 4 weeks. The K-wire was removed 4 weeks after surgery. Weight-bearing posterior–anterior and lateral radiographs were made preoperatively (Figure 3A), immediately postoperatively (Figure 3B), and at the most recent follow-up evaluation (Figure 3C).

caption.p: A, Preoperative radiograph with type 3 deformity. B, Postoperative radiograph; the K-wire is in situ after the osteotomy. C, Followup radiograph after 3 months and remodeled fifth metatarsal bone.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The radiological results showed no pseudarthrosis and a mean medial displacement of 2.5 mm (range 1-4 mm). In type I and type II patients, the MTP decreased from 13° to 4° and in type III the mean MTP decreased from 19.7° to 9.5°. The average postoperative shortening of the fifth metatarsal bone was 1 mm (+1 to −2.5 mm). The mean IM IV/V reduction was 4.5° in all patients. In type I and type II feet, the mean IM IV/V reduced from 9° to 4.5°. In type III feet, the mean IM IV/V reduced from 12° to 7.5°. Functional outcome, as assessed by a postoperative lesser toe AOFAS score showed good and excellent values (80-100 points) in 16 (12 type I, 4 type III) feet. In all, 14 (2 type I, 5 type II, type 7 III) feet were rated as satisfactory (60-80 points) and 1 (type III) foot with fair (56 points). Figures 3A-C show the preoperative, postoperative, and the follow-up radiographs, respectively. No serious complications were noted. There was one foot with a skin inflammatory reaction around the K-wire and consequent early (2 weeks postoperatitve) removal of the K-wire. The osteotomy healed without any further problems and there was no additional operative procedure necessary. Nine (29%) patients (5 type II and 4 type III) indicated they would not undergo the operative procedure again.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Minimal invasive osteotomies with external fixations are reported to have good to excellent clinical results in bunionette deformities.14,21 The aim of our study was to revaluate our results of the minimally invasive osteotomy. We therefore discuss the different features of the minimally invasive technique such as external K-wire fixation, operative approach, and the results with regard to the bunionette deformity type.

The external fixation of the osteotomy with a K-wire has a potential risk of developing pseudarthrosis, delayed union, or dislocation. In biomechanical studies, the K-wire fixation showed less stability than screw fixation. Faraj et al.22 showed a 6 times higher failure load for screw fixation than for wire fixation. Sponsel23 reported delayed union or nonunion in 4 cases after 17 oblique osteotomies with external fixation. Delayed union or nonunion are also possible in cases with internal fixation. Diebold24 reported about 22 basal osteotomies and internal fixation of the fifth metatarsal bone, 4 of them had a delayed union. Okuda et al.15 also reported about a delayed union in patients with an osteotomy at the basis of the fifth metatarsal bone. They postulated a higher risk for delayed union in patients with an osteotomy at the basis and therefore recommended distal osteotomies. The reason could be the confluence of extraosseous vessels along the proximal and medial metatarsal bone as described by Shereff et al.25 Osteotomies at the basis of the metatarsale bone interrupt this confluence and may lead to delayed union or nonunion. In our study, we performed distal osteotomies only with an external K-wire fixation. A nonunion or a delayed union was not present in our series. However, the results with regard to bony healing of the minimal invasive osteotomy by external fixation are not inferior to the current internal fixation techniques, but the weaker fixation may promote a dislocation of the fragments with bony healing in a functional poor position. Moreover, the level of the osteotomy seems to have greater influence on the development of a pseudarthrosis or delayed union than the fixation technique.

A further potential disadvantage of the external pin fixation is the risk of infection from the pin. Giannini et al21 reported one K-wire infection in their series with 50 feet. Legenstein et al.14 reviewed 77 feet with a K-wire fixation and reported about 4 (5%) feet with K-wire infection. We had just one K-wire infection out of a total 30 feet. In this case, the K-wire was removed and no additional therapy was necessary. The union of the osteotomy and the wound healing were without complications. The potential risk of K-wire infection is the disadvantage, but the removal of the K-wire is an easy procedure without further operative risks.

Discomfort because of the hardware irritation in case of internal fixation systems is quite common and a reason for additional operative procedures to remove them. The soft tissue layer over the fifth metatarsal bone is susceptible to impingement by screws or plates. Radl et al16 reported skin irritations because of internal hardware. In their study, 3 of 21 feet had an additional surgery to remove the internal fixation system. In the present study, we used a K-wire for external fixation. These K-wires are a clear disadvantage for the patients during the first 4 weeks.

Postoperative transfermetatarsalgia because of shortening of the fifth metatarsal bone is a problem of oblique distal osteotomies. Keating et al.26 described a postoperative incidence in 36% of the cases after a proximal– medial to distal–lateral osteotomy. The osteotomy in our study goes from lateral–proximal to medial–distal. The oblique displacement of the distal fragment to medial–distal direction therefore reduces the risk of shortening. In our study, we had a mean shortening of 1 mm (+1 to −2.5 mm) at latest follow-up. In spite of the direction of our osteotomy, we do not see a significant lengthening. However, shortening is the result of impaction of the osteotomy and the direction of the osteotomy. The shortening in our study is less than the results reported (−2.6 up to -5 mm) in the literature (Table 1).

sec.p: The limitations of our study are its retrospective character and the absence of a control group. However, until now there has been no prospective randomized study that has compared different techniques. The reported results of the current literature vary in follow-up time and investigated scores (Table 1). The average postoperative lesser toe AOFAS score in our whole study group with 85 points was similar to the results in literature (Table 1). The radiological results of our study with a mean reduction of the MTP of more than 50%, a mean medial displacement of 2.5 mm, and the mean reduction of the IM of 4.5° are in concordance with literature (Table 1). However, in our study there is a discrepancy between the lesser toe AOFAS score and the satisfaction of the patients. One reason could be the weakness of the lesser toe AOFAS score. Button and Pinney27 have reported, in a meta-analysis, the absence of a proven reliable, valid, and responsive rating scale in foot and ankle surgery.

In contrast to our data, Gannini et al.21 reported the minimal invasive distal osteotomy as a technique with less morbidity and a mean AOFAS score of 94 points. Their study group included only grade II and grade III deformities, but they do not report the results separated for the severity groups. A closer look at our results shows that feet with a stage II or III deformity, according to Fallot, show inferior results than type I feet. Thus, we cannot support the good to excellent results of a minimally invasive distal osteotomy reported in the literature for severe deformities. In type II patients, the bending pathology is at the head–neck junction. The bend is not addressed by a distal osteotomy and the pathology might still be present. With regard to the results reported in the literature (Table 1), a diaphyseal osteotomy should be done in type II cases. In patients with a type III pathology, the IV/V IM angle is quite large. The intramedullary K-wire position and the small incision make it difficult to remove excess bone on the lateral aspect of the proximal fragment. A palpable lateral step may be the result and a reason for persistent pain. Also, the displacement is not adjustable individually. In cases with a large IM IV/V, such as in type III patients, the displacement is limited by the intramedullary position of the K-wire. This might be the reason for unsatisfactory results in type III cases. The exposure of the bone and soft tissue for sufficient treatment of these structures is a limiting factor of minimal invasive surgery. The often necessary bursectomy is limited through the 1-cm approach, and therefore, a potential reason for unsatisfied results.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The minimally invasive distal osteotomy with an external K-wire fixation corrects the bony deformity and relieves pain in bunionette deformity. Contrary to current literature publications, the results in type II and III cases are inferior after minimally invasive distal osteotomy. With regard to our results, we do not advise a minimally invasive distal osteotomy in type II and type III cases.
